statement.text: The Stanford Classification divides aortic dissection into two types based on involvement of the ascending aorta: Type A involves the ascending aorta (regardless of origin) and requires emergency surgery; Type B involves only the descending aorta and is initially managed with medical therapy. This simple binary classification directly guides treatment decisions.
statement.formal: Stanford Type A: Ascending aorta involved → Emergency surgical repair | Stanford Type B: Ascending aorta NOT involved (descending only) → Medical management ± TEVAR for complications

explanation.intuition: The Stanford Classification asks one simple question: Is the ascending aorta involved? If yes = Type A = surgery. If no = Type B = medicine. This simplicity is intentional because the ascending aorta is the 'danger zone' - dissection here can tear into the coronary arteries (causing heart attack), the pericardium (causing tamponade), or the aortic valve (causing heart failure). Time is everything in Type A, so a binary classification that immediately dictates treatment is more useful than a detailed anatomic description.
explanation.key_insight: Stanford Type A requires surgery not because surgery is easy, but because NOT operating is uniformly fatal. With medical management alone, Type A mortality is 1-2% per hour in the first 48 hours. Even with emergency surgery carrying 15-25% mortality, it's still far better than the alternative.
explanation.technical_details: The classification was proposed by Daily and colleagues at Stanford in 1970 to simplify the DeBakey system for treatment planning. Type A includes DeBakey Types I and II; Type B corresponds to DeBakey Type III. Important nuances: (1) Retrograde dissection - an entry tear in descending aorta that propagates retrograde into ascending = Type A; (2) Arch involvement - isolated arch without ascending = controversial, some treat as Type A; (3) Post-surgical - dissection after prior ascending aortic surgery depends on new dissection location.
common_misconceptions: Type A means the tear is in the ascending aorta - the tear location doesn't matter, only whether ascending is involved
Type B is benign - mortality is still 10-15% and complications can be lethal
Arch involvement = Type A - isolated arch is debated; usually treated as Type A
Stanford has replaced DeBakey - both are still used; Stanford for treatment, DeBakey for anatomic detail

definitions_glossary.ascending_aorta: Portion of aorta from aortic valve to innominate artery origin
definitions_glossary.descending_aorta: Portion of aorta from left subclavian artery to aortic bifurcation
definitions_glossary.aortic_arch: Curved portion between ascending and descending aorta
definitions_glossary.retrograde_dissection: Dissection propagating backwards against normal blood flow
definitions_glossary.complicated_type_b: Type B with malperfusion, rupture, refractory pain, or rapid expansion

type_a.entry_tear_location: Can be anywhere (ascending, arch, or descending with retrograde extension)

type_b.definition: Dissection confined to descending aorta (distal to left subclavian)
type_b.entry_tear_location: Typically just distal to left subclavian

debakey_i.description: Origin in ascending, extends to descending

debakey_iiia.description: Origin in descending, confined to thorax

debakey_iiib.description: Origin in descending, extends to abdomen

type_a: Immediate transfer to cardiac surgery center
Goal: Exclude entry tear, prevent rupture/tamponade
type_b_uncomplicated: Serial imaging to monitor for complications
type_b_complicated: Coverage of entry tear to promote false lumen thrombosis
Open surgery if endovascular options fail

definition.@value: Binary classification of aortic dissection based on ascending aorta involvement

sources.citation: Daily PO, et al. Management of acute aortic dissections. Ann Thorac Surg. 1970;10:237-247.
2010 ACCF/AHA Guidelines for Thoracic Aortic Disease

learning_objectives: Distinguish Type A from Type B dissection
Explain why ascending involvement dictates surgical management
Convert between Stanford and DeBakey classifications
Identify the treatment approach for each type
clinical_pearls: Stanford asks ONE question: Is the ascending aorta involved?
Type A = Ascending = Surgery (regardless of tear location)
Type B = Below (left subclavian) = Medical management first
Retrograde dissection from descending into ascending = Type A
